items.title: I can identify the five food groups in the Australian Guide to Healthy Eating
items.what: The five food groups are: vegetables and legumes/beans; fruit; grain (cereal) foods; lean meats, poultry, fish, eggs, tofu, nuts, seeds and legumes; and milk, yoghurt, cheese and alternatives.
items.why: Each food group provides different essential nutrients. Eating from all five groups ensures your body gets the variety of vitamins, minerals, protein, carbohydrates and fats it needs.
items.example: Legumes like chickpeas and lentils belong to two food groups - they count as both a vegetable AND a protein source because they provide nutrients from both groups.

subtopic.name: Healthy Eating and Nutrition
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the Australian Dietary Guidelines, the five food groups, recommended daily serves for adolescents, and the concept of nutrient density. You will learn to distinguish between nutritious foods and discretionary foods.
subtopic.why: Understanding nutrition guidelines helps you make informed food choices that support your health, growth, and energy needs. These concepts form the foundation for planning balanced meals and evaluating the nutritional quality of foods.

items.title: I can describe what constitutes one serve from each food group
items.what: A standard serve is a specific quantity that allows consistent measurement across food types. Serve sizes vary between food groups based on their nutrient and energy content.
items.why: Knowing serve sizes helps you track whether you are meeting recommended daily intakes and allows you to plan balanced meals accurately.
items.example: One serve of protein foods is 65g cooked lean red meat (about palm size), 2 large eggs, or 1 cup cooked legumes. One serve of dairy is 1 cup (250ml) milk or 2 slices (40g) of hard cheese.

items.title: I can state the recommended daily serves for adolescents aged 12-14
items.what: The Australian Dietary Guidelines specify how many serves from each food group adolescents need daily, which varies slightly by age and sex.
items.why: Adolescents have higher nutritional needs due to rapid growth and development. Meeting these recommendations supports healthy bone development, brain function, and energy levels.
items.example: A 13-year-old girl needs 5 serves of vegetables, 2 serves of fruit, 5 serves of grains, 2.5 serves of protein foods, and 3.5 serves of dairy daily, plus 1.4-1.6 litres of water.

items.title: I can explain what discretionary foods are and why they should be limited
items.what: Discretionary foods are high in energy (kilojoules) but low in beneficial nutrients. They are high in saturated fat, added sugars, or salt and are not part of the five food groups.
items.why: Consuming too many discretionary foods can lead to weight gain and health problems while displacing more nutritious options from your diet.
items.example: One serve of discretionary food (600kJ) equals about 2 scoops of ice cream, one-third of a meat pie, or 1 small packet of chips (30g). The guidelines recommend limiting these to a maximum of one serve per day.

subtopic.why: Understanding nutrition guidelines helps you make informed food choices that support your health, growth, and energy needs. These concepts form the foundation for planning balanced meals and evaluating the nutritional quality of foods.

items.title: I can explain the concept of nutrient density and compare foods using this concept
items.what: Nutrient density measures how many beneficial nutrients a food provides relative to its energy (kilojoule) content. High nutrient-dense foods provide lots of vitamins, minerals, and fibre for relatively few kilojoules.
items.why: Choosing nutrient-dense foods helps you meet your nutritional needs without consuming excess energy, supporting healthy weight and overall wellbeing.
items.example: An apple (350kJ) provides fibre, vitamin C, potassium, and antioxidants. A handful of pretzels (350kJ) provides mostly refined carbohydrates. Both have similar energy, but the apple is much more nutrient-dense.

items.title: I can explain why whole fruit is preferable to fruit juice
items.what: When fruit is juiced, the fibre is removed and the natural sugars become more concentrated. Whole fruit takes longer to eat and provides greater satiety.
items.why: Fibre is essential for digestive health and helps slow the absorption of sugars into the bloodstream. Removing fibre means you consume sugar more quickly and feel less full.
items.example: A glass of orange juice contains the sugar from 3-4 oranges but none of the fibre. Eating one whole orange gives you the same vitamins plus 2-3g of fibre and takes longer to consume.

items.title: I can explain the difference between protein denaturation and coagulation
items.what: Denaturation is when a protein's folded structure unravels due to heat, acid, or mechanical action. Coagulation is when denatured proteins bond together to form a solid or semi-solid mass.
items.why: These processes explain why eggs solidify when cooked, why meat changes texture, and why overcooked proteins become tough and dry.
items.example: When you cook an egg white, denaturation causes the proteins to unravel, then coagulation bonds them together into a firm white mass that traps water. This change is permanent - you cannot uncook an egg.

subtopic.name: Food Science: How Cooking Changes Food
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can identify the coagulation temperatures for egg white and egg yolk
items.what: Egg white coagulates at 62-65°C, while egg yolk coagulates at a slightly higher temperature of 65-70°C.
items.why: Knowing these temperatures explains why you can cook a fried egg with a firm white but runny yolk - the white sets at a lower temperature than the yolk.
items.example: A soft-boiled egg cooked for 6 minutes has a fully set white but a jammy yolk because the centre has reached 65-70°C but not been held there long enough to fully coagulate.

subtopic.name: Food Science: How Cooking Changes Food
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can explain how collagen converts to gelatin during slow cooking
items.what: Collagen is tough connective tissue found in cheaper meat cuts. When heated slowly at 70-82°C for 2-4 hours, collagen transforms into soft, silky gelatin.
items.why: This explains why tough cuts like brisket and lamb shanks become tender with slow cooking, while the same cuts would be chewy if grilled quickly.
items.example: Beef brisket contains lots of collagen. Grilling it quickly would result in tough, chewy meat. Braising it at 150°C for 3 hours converts the collagen to gelatin, making it fall-apart tender.

subtopic.name: Food Science: How Cooking Changes Food
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can describe the process of starch gelatinisation
items.what: Gelatinisation occurs when starch granules are heated in liquid. Around 60°C they absorb water and swell; at 96°C they burst, releasing starch molecules that thicken the liquid.
items.why: Understanding gelatinisation helps you make smooth sauces, understand why stirring prevents lumps, and know when a sauce has reached its maximum thickness.
items.example: When making a white sauce, you heat flour in milk while stirring constantly. At 96°C, the starch granules burst and release their starch, thickening the sauce. If you add all the milk at once without stirring, the granules clump together creating lumps.

subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can explain why bread stored in the fridge goes stale faster than bread at room temperature
items.what: Staling is caused by retrogradation - when gelatinised starch molecules slowly reorganise and recrystallise, pushing water out. This process happens fastest at refrigerator temperatures (around 4°C).
items.why: Understanding retrogradation helps you store bread correctly and explains why toasting can temporarily refresh stale bread by reversing the process.
items.example: Bread stored in the fridge will go stale in 1-2 days, while bread at room temperature takes 3-4 days. For longer storage, freezing is best because it essentially stops retrogradation.

subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can describe the Maillard reaction and identify when it occurs
items.what: The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs above 140°C in dry conditions. It creates brown colour, complex flavours, and appealing aromas.
items.why: The Maillard reaction is responsible for the delicious flavours in toast, seared meat, roasted coffee, and baked goods. Understanding it helps you achieve better browning in cooking.
items.example: Boiled potatoes are pale because the water limits temperature to 100°C. Roasted potatoes turn golden brown because the dry oven heat reaches 200°C, allowing the Maillard reaction to occur.

subtopic.name: Food Science: How Cooking Changes Food
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can explain the difference between the Maillard reaction and caramelisation
items.what: The Maillard reaction requires amino acids plus sugars and occurs around 140°C, creating savoury, complex flavours. Caramelisation is the browning of sugars alone at higher temperatures (160-180°C), creating sweet flavours.
items.why: Knowing the difference helps you understand why different foods brown differently and produce distinct flavour profiles.
items.example: A seared steak undergoes the Maillard reaction (proteins + sugars = meaty, nutty flavours). Caramel sauce undergoes caramelisation (sugars only = sweet, butterscotch flavours).

subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can explain how emulsifiers help oil and water mix
items.what: An emulsifier has a hydrophilic (water-loving) end and a hydrophobic (oil-loving) end. It positions itself at the boundary between oil and water droplets, coating each droplet and preventing separation.
items.why: Understanding emulsification explains why mayonnaise stays creamy instead of separating, and why adding oil slowly is essential when making emulsified sauces.
items.example: Mayonnaise is an emulsion of oil and vinegar. Lecithin in egg yolk acts as the emulsifier. If oil is added too quickly, the lecithin cannot coat all the droplets and the mayonnaise splits into oily and watery layers.

subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the chemical and physical changes that occur when food is cooked. You will learn about protein denaturation and coagulation, starch gelatinisation, the Maillard reaction, emulsification, and how acids affect food.
subtopic.why: Understanding food science helps you predict how ingredients will behave during cooking, troubleshoot problems, and make better decisions about cooking methods. This knowledge transforms you from someone who follows recipes to someone who understands why recipes work.

items.title: I can distinguish between wet and dry cooking methods
items.what: Wet (moist heat) methods use water or other liquids as the cooking medium and are limited to 100°C. Dry heat methods use hot air, fat, or direct heat and can reach much higher temperatures.
items.why: Wet methods cannot produce browning because water limits temperature. Dry methods can achieve the high temperatures needed for the Maillard reaction and caramelisation.
items.example: Steaming broccoli (wet method) keeps it green and tender but not browned. Roasting broccoli (dry method) at 200°C creates caramelised, crispy edges with nutty flavours.

subtopic.name: Cooking Methods and Techniques
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers wet and dry cooking methods, their characteristics, and how to select appropriate methods based on food properties. You will learn about boiling, simmering, steaming, poaching, braising, baking, roasting, grilling, and frying.
subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can identify appropriate cooking methods for tender versus tough cuts of meat
items.what: Tender cuts (fillet, chicken breast) have little connective tissue and suit quick, high-heat methods like grilling. Tough cuts (brisket, shanks) have lots of collagen and need slow cooking methods like braising.
items.why: Tender cuts become tough if overcooked. Tough cuts become tender only when slow cooking converts their collagen to gelatin over 2-4 hours.
items.example: Grilling a lamb shank would result in tough, chewy meat. Braising the same shank for 3 hours makes it fall-off-the-bone tender. Conversely, braising a fillet steak would make it mushy and flavourless.

subtopic.name: Cooking Methods and Techniques
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers wet and dry cooking methods, their characteristics, and how to select appropriate methods based on food properties. You will learn about boiling, simmering, steaming, poaching, braising, baking, roasting, grilling, and frying.
subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can explain why steaming is the best cooking method for preserving nutrients
items.what: Steaming cooks food above boiling water without direct contact. Water-soluble vitamins (vitamin C and B vitamins) cannot leach into the cooking water because the food never touches it.
items.why: When vegetables are boiled, water-soluble vitamins dissolve into the cooking water and are often discarded. Steaming preserves these nutrients in the food.
items.example: Boiled broccoli can lose 25-50% of its vitamin C to the cooking water. Steamed broccoli retains most of its vitamin C because it never touches the water.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers wet and dry cooking methods, their characteristics, and how to select appropriate methods based on food properties. You will learn about boiling, simmering, steaming, poaching, braising, baking, roasting, grilling, and frying.
subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can describe the difference between boiling, simmering, and poaching temperatures
items.what: Boiling is 100°C with large, rapidly breaking bubbles. Simmering is 85-96°C with gentle bubbles rising to the surface. Poaching is 70-85°C with barely any bubbles - just a shimmer on the surface.
items.why: Different temperatures suit different foods. Boiling is too violent for delicate foods like eggs and fish. Poaching and simmering are gentler and maintain moisture.
items.example: A poached egg cooks gently at 70-85°C, allowing the white to set softly around a runny yolk. Boiling an egg in rapidly bubbling water would cause the white to become rubbery and the egg to bounce around and break.

subtopic.name: Cooking Methods and Techniques
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers wet and dry cooking methods, their characteristics, and how to select appropriate methods based on food properties. You will learn about boiling, simmering, steaming, poaching, braising, baking, roasting, grilling, and frying.
subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can explain how braising combines wet and dry cooking methods
items.what: Braising starts with searing at high heat (dry method for Maillard flavour), then slow-cooking partially covered in liquid at 135-165°C for 2-4 hours (wet method for collagen conversion).
items.why: Braising combines the benefits of both methods - the complex flavours from browning and the tenderising effect of slow, moist cooking.
items.example: To braise lamb shanks: sear them in a hot pan until browned all over, add stock and aromatics, cover and cook in a 150°C oven for 3 hours until the meat is tender and falling off the bone.

subtopic.name: Cooking Methods and Techniques
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers wet and dry cooking methods, their characteristics, and how to select appropriate methods based on food properties. You will learn about boiling, simmering, steaming, poaching, braising, baking, roasting, grilling, and frying.
subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can explain why delicate foods require gentle cooking methods
items.what: Delicate foods like fish, eggs, and chicken breast have properties that require gentle handling - fish flakes easily and dries out quickly, eggs set rapidly, and chicken breast is low in fat so dries out easily.
items.why: High, dry heat will overcook delicate foods before the interior is cooked through, resulting in dry, tough, or broken textures.
items.example: Poaching is ideal for salmon fillets because the gentle 70-85°C temperature cooks the fish evenly without drying it out. Grilling salmon on high heat often results in overcooked edges and undercooked centre.

subtopic.why: Choosing the right cooking method is essential for achieving the best texture, flavour, and nutritional value. Understanding why certain methods suit certain foods helps you become a more skilled and confident cook.

items.title: I can identify the mandatory information required on Australian food labels
items.what: Australian food labels must include: food name, ingredient list, date marking, Nutrition Information Panel, allergen declarations, manufacturer details, country of origin, and net weight/volume.
items.why: Knowing what must appear on labels helps you find the information you need and identify when labelling may be incomplete or incorrect.
items.example: A packaged muesli bar must display all mandatory information. Foods made and sold on the same premises (like bakery items) or very small packages under 100cm² are exempt from some requirements.

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can use the per 100g column to fairly compare the nutritional content of different products
items.what: The Nutrition Information Panel has two columns: per serve and per 100g. Per 100g is the standardised measure that allows fair comparison between products regardless of serving size.
items.why: Manufacturers choose their own serving sizes, often making them small to make numbers look better. Per 100g provides a consistent basis for comparison.
items.example: Cereal A has 24g sugar per 100g (high). Cereal B has 3.8g sugar per 100g (low). Even if their per-serve columns look similar due to different serving sizes, per 100g reveals Cereal B is the lower-sugar option.

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can interpret nutrient levels as low, medium, or high using standard thresholds
items.what: Standard thresholds help interpret nutrient levels: sugar is low at 5g or less per 100g and high above 15g; sodium is low below 120mg and high above 400mg per 100g; saturated fat is low at 1.5g or less per 100g.
items.why: These thresholds help you quickly assess whether a food is a healthy choice for nutrients you should limit.
items.example: A pasta sauce with 8g sugar per 100g is medium (between 5g and 15g). A sauce with 480mg sodium per 100g is high (above 400mg threshold) and should be consumed in moderation.

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can explain the difference between use-by and best-before dates
items.what: Use-by dates relate to food safety - food may become unsafe after this date and should not be consumed. Best-before dates relate to quality - food is still safe after this date but may have declined in quality.
items.why: Understanding this difference helps prevent food waste while ensuring food safety. Many people discard food unnecessarily after best-before dates.
items.example: Fresh chicken past its use-by date should be discarded even if it looks fine. A can of beans two months past its best-before date is still safe to eat if the can is undamaged.

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can explain how allergens must be declared on Australian food labels
items.what: Mandatory allergens must be highlighted in bold in the ingredient list AND listed in a separate Contains statement. The specific type must be named for tree nuts, fish, crustaceans, and molluscs.
items.why: Food allergies can be life-threatening. Clear allergen labelling helps people with allergies avoid dangerous reactions.
items.example: A product containing almonds must show: Ingredients including almonds in bold, PLUS Contains: Tree nuts (almonds). May contain statements (like May contain traces of peanuts) are voluntary warnings about cross-contamination.

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can interpret ingredient lists to identify the main components of a food
items.what: Ingredients are listed in descending order by weight - the first ingredient is present in the largest amount. Multiple types of the same ingredient (like different sugars) can make it appear lower on the list.
items.why: Reading ingredient lists helps you understand what you are really eating and identify products high in sugar, fat, or additives.
items.example: An ingredient list starting with wheat flour, sugar, vegetable oil, glucose syrup tells you the product is mainly flour with significant sugar content (sugar is second AND glucose syrup is fourth - two types of added sugar).

subtopic.name: Reading and Interpreting Food Labels
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Australian food labelling requirements regulated by FSANZ. You will learn to interpret Nutrition Information Panels, ingredient lists, allergen declarations, date marking, Health Star Ratings, and nutrition claims.
subtopic.why: Food labels provide essential information for making informed choices about what you eat. Understanding labels helps you compare products, identify allergens, avoid food waste, and make healthier selections.

items.title: I can evaluate nutrition content claims like reduced fat and no added sugar
items.what: Nutrition claims are regulated and must meet specific criteria. Reduced fat means at least 25% less fat than the regular version, but the product may still be high in fat. No added sugar means no sugar was added, but natural sugars may still be present.
items.why: Understanding what claims actually mean helps you avoid being misled by marketing language and make truly informed choices.
items.example: A reduced fat cheese with 25% less fat than regular cheese could still have 24g fat per 100g if the original had 32g. No added sugar fruit juice still contains concentrated natural sugars from the fruit.

items.title: I can identify and describe the five basic taste sensations
items.what: The five basic tastes are sweet (sugars), sour (acids), salty (sodium chloride), bitter (various compounds), and umami (glutamate). Each taste serves an evolutionary purpose in identifying nutritious or dangerous foods.
items.why: Understanding the five tastes helps you analyse flavours in food and understand how different tastes interact and balance each other.
items.example: Umami (meaning deliciousness in Japanese) is found in Parmesan cheese, tomatoes, mushrooms, and Vegemite. It was identified by Dr Kikunae Ikeda in 1908 and signals protein-rich foods.

subtopic.name: Sensory Evaluation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how we perceive food through our senses, including the five basic tastes, the multi-sensory eating experience, texture vocabulary, and formal sensory evaluation methods used in food science.
subtopic.why: Understanding sensory evaluation helps you describe food more precisely, understand why certain flavour combinations work, and conduct fair tests to compare food products objectively.

items.title: I can explain why the tongue map is a myth
items.what: The tongue map showing different areas tasting different things is scientifically incorrect. Taste receptors for all five tastes are distributed across the entire tongue - you can taste any taste anywhere on your tongue.
items.why: Understanding this corrects a common misconception and reflects accurate scientific knowledge about how taste perception works.
items.example: If you place salt on the very tip of your tongue, you will taste it immediately - proving that saltiness is not restricted to the sides of the tongue as the myth suggests.

subtopic.name: Sensory Evaluation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how we perceive food through our senses, including the five basic tastes, the multi-sensory eating experience, texture vocabulary, and formal sensory evaluation methods used in food science.
subtopic.why: Understanding sensory evaluation helps you describe food more precisely, understand why certain flavour combinations work, and conduct fair tests to compare food products objectively.

items.title: I can explain how tastes interact with each other
items.what: Tastes interact in predictable ways: salt enhances sweetness and reduces bitterness; sweet and sour balance each other; umami can reduce the need for salt; sweet masks bitterness.
items.why: Understanding taste interactions helps cooks balance flavours in dishes and explains why certain flavour combinations are popular.
items.example: Salted caramel works because salt enhances the perception of sweetness. Adding Parmesan (umami) to pasta means you need less salt because umami provides satisfying savoury depth.

subtopic.name: Sensory Evaluation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how we perceive food through our senses, including the five basic tastes, the multi-sensory eating experience, texture vocabulary, and formal sensory evaluation methods used in food science.
subtopic.why: Understanding sensory evaluation helps you describe food more precisely, understand why certain flavour combinations work, and conduct fair tests to compare food products objectively.

items.title: I can explain the role of smell in flavour perception
items.what: Approximately 80% of what we perceive as taste actually comes from smell. Aromas reach our smell receptors through orthonasal (through nostrils) and retronasal (from mouth to nose while eating) pathways.
items.why: Understanding the importance of smell explains why food tastes bland when you have a cold and why aroma is crucial to the eating experience.
items.example: When you have a blocked nose from a cold, food seems flavourless because you cannot smell it. The complex flavours of coffee or wine come largely from hundreds of volatile aroma compounds.

subtopic.name: Sensory Evaluation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how we perceive food through our senses, including the five basic tastes, the multi-sensory eating experience, texture vocabulary, and formal sensory evaluation methods used in food science.
subtopic.why: Understanding sensory evaluation helps you describe food more precisely, understand why certain flavour combinations work, and conduct fair tests to compare food products objectively.

items.title: I can use appropriate vocabulary to describe food texture
items.what: Texture descriptors include: crispy (light, shatters easily), crunchy (firm, requires force), chewy (requires prolonged chewing), tender (easy to bite), tough (difficult to chew), smooth, creamy, flaky, crumbly, moist, dry, and juicy.
items.why: Precise texture vocabulary allows you to communicate about food effectively and is essential for sensory evaluation and recipe development.
items.example: A potato chip is crispy (light, shatters with a high-pitched sound), while a raw carrot is crunchy (firm, requires force to bite through with a cracking sound). These are different textures despite both being snappy.

subtopic.name: Sensory Evaluation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how we perceive food through our senses, including the five basic tastes, the multi-sensory eating experience, texture vocabulary, and formal sensory evaluation methods used in food science.
subtopic.why: Understanding sensory evaluation helps you describe food more precisely, understand why certain flavour combinations work, and conduct fair tests to compare food products objectively.

items.title: I can describe how to conduct a fair triangle test
items.what: In a triangle test, tasters receive three samples (two identical, one different) labelled with random 3-digit codes. They must identify the odd one out. The chance of guessing correctly is 33%.
items.why: Triangle tests determine if people can detect differences between products, which is useful when testing recipe changes or comparing similar products objectively.
items.example: To test if consumers notice reduced salt in a recipe, serve three coded samples (two original, one reduced salt) to multiple tasters. If significantly more than 33% identify the odd one out, there is a detectable difference.

items.title: I can explain how to eliminate bias in sensory testing
items.what: Fair sensory tests require: blind testing with random codes (not names); randomised presentation order; no talking between tasters; same temperature, quantity, and containers; palate cleansers between samples; immediate recording of results.
items.why: Bias can significantly affect results. Knowing a sample is new recipe versus old recipe, or discussing with others, can influence perception and make results unreliable.
items.example: Labelling samples Sample A and Sample B creates bias because people may assume A is better. Using random 3-digit codes like 472, 815, and 293 eliminates this bias.

items.title: I can classify foods using the NOVA processing system
items.what: The NOVA system has four groups: Group 1 (unprocessed/minimally processed foods), Group 2 (processed culinary ingredients like oil and sugar), Group 3 (processed foods like cheese and canned vegetables), and Group 4 (ultra-processed foods).
items.why: High consumption of ultra-processed foods is linked to health problems including obesity and heart disease. Recognising processing levels helps you make healthier choices.
items.example: Fresh apple (Group 1), sugar (Group 2), canned apple in syrup (Group 3), apple-flavoured fruit snack with added colours and preservatives (Group 4). About 42% of energy in Australian diets comes from ultra-processed foods.

subtopic.name: Contemporary Food Issues
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores current issues in food systems including ultra-processed foods, food miles, environmental impact, food waste, convenience foods, and packaging. You will learn to evaluate food choices for both health and sustainability.
subtopic.why: Food choices affect not just personal health but also the environment and society. Understanding contemporary food issues helps you make informed decisions that consider the broader impacts of what you eat.

items.title: I can identify characteristics of ultra-processed foods
items.what: Ultra-processed foods typically have: long ingredient lists (5+ ingredients), ingredients not used in home cooking (high-fructose corn syrup, protein isolates), and cosmetic additives (colours, emulsifiers, thickeners).
items.why: Being able to identify ultra-processed foods from their labels helps you make informed choices about what to eat.
items.example: A packaged snack listing wheat flour, sugar, glucose syrup, hydrogenated vegetable oil, maltodextrin, colour (102), flavour, and emulsifier (471) is ultra-processed - it contains multiple ingredients you would not use at home.

items.title: I can explain why food miles alone are not always a good indicator of environmental impact
items.what: How food is produced often matters more than how far it travels. Heated greenhouses, intensive farming, and production methods can generate more emissions than transport, even for local foods.
items.why: Understanding this complexity helps you make more informed choices about sustainable eating rather than relying on simple assumptions.
items.example: New Zealand lamb exported to the UK produces about four times less carbon emissions than UK-raised lamb because New Zealand's climate allows grass-fed farming with minimal inputs. Ending all international food transport would only reduce food system emissions by about 9%.

items.title: I can compare the environmental footprint of different foods
items.what: Foods have vastly different environmental impacts. Beef produces 36-100 kg CO2 per kg, while vegetables produce under 1 kg CO2 per kg. Beef also requires 15,415 litres of water per kg compared to 322 litres for vegetables.
items.why: Understanding these differences helps you make food choices that reduce your environmental impact.
items.example: Beef produces about 6 times more greenhouse gases than chicken per 50g of protein, and up to 100 times more than legumes. Eating more plants and less red meat is one of the most effective ways to reduce your food footprint.

items.title: I can describe the scale of food waste in Australia and its environmental impact
items.what: Australia wastes 7.6 million tonnes of food per year (312 kg per person). About 70% could have been eaten. Households are the biggest source at 32%. Food waste in landfill releases methane, which is 28 times more potent than CO2.
items.why: Understanding food waste helps you see why reducing it matters for both your budget and the environment.
items.example: The average Australian household wastes $2,500-$3,800 worth of food per year. The most commonly wasted foods are vegetables (29%), fruit (22%), and bakery items (21%). Understanding date labels alone could significantly reduce this waste.

items.title: I can evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of convenience foods
items.what: Convenience foods save time and require minimal preparation, but are often higher in salt, sugar, and saturated fat, have more packaging, and are usually more expensive than home-prepared equivalents.
items.why: Understanding trade-offs helps you make balanced decisions about when convenience foods are appropriate and which options are healthier.
items.example: Frozen vegetables and canned legumes are healthy convenience options - nutrients are preserved by flash-freezing, and canned legumes just need rinsing. Mass-produced frozen meals often contain high sodium and multiple additives.

items.title: I can identify strategies to reduce food waste at home
items.what: Strategies include: meal planning and shopping lists, understanding date labels (best-before means quality not safety), proper food storage, using leftovers creatively, first-in-first-out rotation, and composting.
items.why: Reducing food waste saves money and reduces environmental impact. Many strategies are simple habits that become automatic with practice.
items.example: A can of beans two months past its best-before date is still safe to eat if undamaged. Understanding this distinction between use-by (safety) and best-before (quality) could prevent unnecessary waste of pantry items.
